reporting-org.narrative: Water & Land Resource Center - Addis Ababa University

title.narrative: Kunzila Integrated Landscape Management and WASH Project

description.narrative: Kunzila Integrated Landscape Management & WASH (KILMWA) is a Five Year (2020-2024) Project that has set out an innovative and comprehensive vision to contribute to a more prosperous and healthy population in Kunzila watershed Participatory Integrated Watershed Management and WASH interventions in alignment with existing initiatives and programmes in the area. The project is funded by The Royal Netherlands Embassy in Ethiopia. The project is implemented by WLRC in partnership with SNV. The project brings together the unique combination of experience and expertise, networks and alliances, and proven approaches the WLRC and SNV have in PIWM and WASH sectors, respectively in Ethiopia, region and globe.

participating-org.narrative: Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN)
Water and Land Resource Center of Addis Ababa University
Water and Land Resource Center of Addis Ababa University

activity-date.narrative: It is the date where WLRC signed the contract with EKN
It was planned to start immediately

organisation.narrative: Water and Land Resource Center of Addis Ababa University

description.narrative: A total budget of € 121890 was allocated to finance development activities planned under Outcome8: Efficient and responsive project management, facilitation of timely implementation, and functional MEL. The utilization was 47.8% of the planned budget. The reasons are some of the joint management activities, PSC meetings at woreda and regional levels, were not implemented due to political instability, election, etc. and more attention was given to kick start the project at the site level, and some required materials for KWT/CWF were not procured as their office was not finalized.

A total budget of € 175996 was allocated to finance development activities planned under Outcome7: Modern setups and systems for scientific monitoring in Kunzila Watershed established and preliminary findings verified. The reason for the utilization of above the planned budget was that the 40% payment for ACACIA was above the planned budget when it also includes the 15% tax.

A total budget of € 259881 was allocated to finance development activities planned under Outcome 1: Watersheds are managed sustainably and ecosystem services enhance. The project utilized 101.1% of the allocated budget. The reason for excess was that developing nurseries demanded employment of additional daily laborers, which raised the expenditure a bit.

A total budget of € 291256 was allocated to finance development activities planned under Outcome3: Outcome 3: Improved capacities of institutions, community organizations, and groups for sustainable natural resource management and livelihoods. Many training and manual preparations/publications were not fully implemented during the budget year as time was against us and are pushed to the next year.

A total budget of € 452,943 was allocated to finance development activities planned under Outcome 2: Agricultural productivity and livelihoods enhanced. From this budget, 56.4% of the budget was utilized during the reporting period. The planned tractors and machinery for RUTH were not purchased due to a change in approach. In addition, there were delays in the implementation of homestead packages for many reasons such as the need for forage preparation, finalization of the credit system, etc.

A total fund of € 771,288.42 allocated to finance program costs, indirect costs such as office rent, headquarter staff, salaries of the project staff, etc. From this, the project utilized 76.1%. Delay in the employment of drivers (due to the delay in the purchases of vehicles), finding a reputable management consultant took a long time.

A total of € 936,542.53 was planned to finance the purchases of equipment, supplies, and other expenditures including travel-related expenses. Of this, 40% of the planned budget was utilized. The reasons are that equipment for the monitoring stations was not purchased due to the bureaucratic import system of the country. In addition, diverse inputs for FREG, and other demonstrations were not purchased due to the bureaucratic import system and the delay in some of the homestead activities, respectively. Furthermore, the planned equipment for RUTH was not purchased as we changed our approach.
Expenditure from September 2020 to June for Component 6: Strengthening Multistakeholder WASH under woreda leadership
Expenditure to finance the various inception phase activities
Global in-direct costs (8.5% of programme cost + in-country programme delivery costs) and in-country program management

provider-org.narrative: Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN)

description.narrative: The expenditure is for activities related to strengthening rural WASH services. Of the total budget allocated 459,355.00 allocated for the component, the project utilized 82.5%. The surplus is due to the delay in payments for construction and other related activities.

The expenditure is to finance project activities of Strengthening Urban WASH component. From the total Euro 84064 allocated for the specific component, the project utilized 78.3% of the budget in the periods between Sept 2020 to June 2021 which is equal to Euro 65843.56. Likewise, the delay in the construction and shortage of cement in the market were the main reasons for the 21.7% surplus.
The first disbursement to WLRC for Integrated Landscape Management related activities of the project

provider-org.narrative: Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN)

title.narrative: Annual report of Kunzila Integrated Landscape Management and WASH Project, September 2020 to June 2021

description.narrative: The annual report describes development interventions implemented by the project during the reporting period from September 2020 to June 2021. The project started in March 2020. The first phase of the project was the inception phase which runs from March 2020 to August 2020. After completing its inception phase in August 2020, the project has entered into its implementation phase since September 2020. The project constitutes two sectors: the Integrated Landscape Management (ILM) sector and WASH sector which are implemented by Water & Land Resource Center (WLRC) and SNV, respectively. WLRC is the lead organization.

title.narrative: People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities.

description.narrative: People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities including hand washing and soap

title.narrative: number of people living in open defecation free communities. - bas

comment.narrative: Since demand triggering is conducted lately, no ODF kebeles declared yet. However, a total of 8562 people stop open defecation and are using toilet facilities

title.narrative: Institutional WASH
Number of students benefited with improved drinking water sna dsanitation facility

comment.narrative: A total of 2851 girl students in 5 schools will be accessible to toilet facilities in Sep 2021 when the schools will be open, and the status of the toilet construction is 70% at this stage. Besides, maintenance of toilets for boy students in 2 urban schools is undergoing to sustain toilet uses for 1643 boy students. On the other hand, access to improve water supply is not yet done.

The plan was to construct three blocks of School Toilets in three schools. The construction of 3 block toilets for girls with 4 seats and handwashing facilities has already started in Kanchaye, Forhe #1 and Forhe #2 schools. But the toilets are not only completed. Thus, there are no beneficiary students now. But more than 5000 students will benefit from the toilets.

title.narrative: Institutional WASH
Number of sanitary facilities constructed in public places
Integrated water resource management
Degree of integrated water resource management implementation (1-10)

comment.narrative: The degree of water resource management implementation (1-10) in the baseline situation was rated as 1 (very weak). The project targeted to raise this rating to 3. The project implemented several activities such as the construction of two community ponds, the construction of diverse soil and water conservation activities through community mobilizations, the construction of a diversion canal, and the like. Despite these efforts, the performances were limited especially in implementing conservation works that raise the rating from 1 only to 2.

title.narrative: Institutional WASH
Number of health care facilitites with improved dringking water and sanitation facilities
River basin management
Number of people benefiting from improved river basin management

comment.narrative: A number of activities that benefit many farmers were planned to be implemented through community mobilization. Almost no community mobilization works have been performed elsewhere in the region due to the existing political conflict and security problems. But the project was able to mobilize communities to implement some activities such as SWC works, gully treatment, area exclusion, etc. Though the performance vis-a-vis the plan is not good, it was a great success compared to other areas. The project implemented diverse activities that benefited 672 farmers.

title.narrative: People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities.
number of people using safely managed drinking water services (SDG 6.1.1) - basic
Nutrition improvement
Number of smallscale producers directly reached with activities to increase productivity/income

comment.narrative: The project planned to reach 784 small-scale producers with activities to increase productivity/income. The project designed diverse interventions to reach the smallscale producers by promoting productivity/income raising technologies on production of vegetables, fruits, cash crops (gesho, coffee), livestock production (fattening, poultry, beekeeping, sheep breeding, dairy, etc.), field crops (improved variety, introduction of new crop - upland rice, fertility management), and by enabling you to acquire special skills demanded by the market, etc. In the project year, 609 smallscale producers are reached with one or more of the above technologies. Access to credit service was the main reason for low performance. The project is working to address this problem through the Saving and Credit Cooperatives operating in the areas.

title.narrative: People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities.
number of people using safely managed sanitation services, including a handwashing facility with soap and water (SDG 6.1.2) - m

comment.narrative: A total of 1072 new people are using safely managed toilets but none of them had handwashing facilities with soap since SBCC outreach campaign is not yet done.

title.narrative: Nutrition improvement
Hectares of farmland directly reached with activities to improve eco-efficiency

comment.narrative: Based on the baseline study, areas of farmlands reached with improved eco-efficiency was 298 ha. In 2020-2021 project year, the project has reached an additional 617.8 ha of farmland with different activities that improve the eco-efficiency of the land. These interventions include construction of SWC works; planting of grass-strips; promotion of composts and treating acidic soils with lime. Furthermore, the promotion of fuel-saving stoves is also another eco-efficiency technology.

title.narrative: Water supply
Number of drinking water points constructed
Nutrition improvement
Number of people directly reached with activiteis to improve nutrition

comment.narrative: To improve the nutritional status of households, the project implemented various interventions by implementing integrated homestead packages that are implemented in the backyard of households. The homestead package is a bundle of technologies consisting of vegetable production, fruit production, poultry production, beekeeping, dairy production, sheep/goat production etc. The aim is to encourage farmers to use portions of these products for household consumption. Demonstrating improved food preparation is also part of the intervention. A total of 439 households have participated in at least three of the above homestead packages.

title.narrative: Climate
Hectars of forest(ed) land under sustainable managemnt or other improved practices

comment.narrative: Based on the baseline survey, the baseline forest(ed) land in the project area was 499 ha. The project planned to increase this area to 1100 in the implementation period of 2020-2021. Of, 146.5 ha of land is forested through diverse strategies such as treatment of gullies with the planting of forage trees, multipurpose trees, and grasses splits which amount to 40.5 ha of land. Similar interventions were also made through area closure of degraded lands and by planting different trees. Accordingly, 89 ha of land is closed from human and livestock contact. To ensure the sustainability of the area closure of degraded land and gully, 39 and 38 resource user associations are established for the gully and degraded lands that are closed. Furthermore, afforestation of communal lands and hillsides was also done on 17 ha of land. These interventions increased the previous 499 ha of forest land to 645.5 ha. Community mobilization and enforcement problems were the major reason for poor the performances
